article.title: 10 Isla Vista Commandments
article.description: Trumpeted by the thundering waves, bellowing frat boys and wailing sirens of a Friday night in Isla Vista, the great Chancellor Yang descended upon one unworthy Nexus writer to set forth a set of rule...
article.content:
Trumpeted by the thundering waves, bellowing frat boys and wailing sirens of a Friday night in Isla Vista, the great Chancellor Yang descended upon one unworthy Nexus writer to set forth a set of rules to govern the students of UCSB.

1.) Thou shalt not covet thy roommate’s friend with benefits.

2.) Thou shalt not steal another student’s bike (even if it is a beach cruiser and thou thinketh thou art doing them a favor).

3.) Thou shalt not forgo the opportunity to yell “Fuck FT” whenever thou passes said towers.

4.) Thou shalt not walk on the bike paths.

5.) Thou shalt not invite out-of-towners on Halloween and Deltopia weekends.

6.) Thou shalt refrain from taking the end seats in Campbell Hall and sighing dramatically when people need to squeeze past thou (thou shalt also only take up thou’s designated armrest space).

7.) Thou shalt not pass up the opportunity for free food and/or scantrons.

8.) Thou shalt not make eye contact with strangers tabling at the Arbor.

9.) Thou shalt not waste Freebirds nachos when thou has made the horrible mistake of purchasing said food.

10.) Thou shalt always Gaucho back.

Print

related.title: DIY Ugly Christmas Sweater Guide
related.description: A step-by-step guide to uglifying a perfectly good sweater, just in time for the holiday season! Hopefully this guide inspires the mediocre DIY artists of our generation, as well as the people who are...
related.content:
A step-by-step guide to uglifying a perfectly good sweater, just in time for the holiday season! Hopefully this guide inspires the mediocre DIY artists of our generation, as well as the people who are stuck at home and happen to be incredibly bored.

Step 1: Purchase a sweater. It can be a fuzzy, knit one, a basic sweatshirt or one from a club or band you used to care about. Lay the sweater out and examine your options.

Jasmine Vaughn // Daily Nexus

Step 2: Start brainstorming ideas. Try to choose a decorative medium that represents you as a person. For this example I will be using pasta and glitter, but don’t feel restricted to those two items. You do you, Booboo.

Jasmine Vaughn / Daily Nexus

Step 3: Lay out a basic pattern for your sweater design. This is where you get to play around with shapes and designs before making a commitment, which is terrifying because commitment is scary because we are millennials. #relatable.

Jasmine Vaughn / Daily Nexus

Step 4: Glue all your shit down. Alfredo sauce can be used as a possible glue substitute. 

Jasmine Vaughn / Daily Nexus

Step 5: Take a moment to pour yourself a glass of something because you earned it. I chose pomegranate juice because I’m still at the tender young age of 19 and I’m staying with my parents for the holidays. 

Jasmine Vaughn / Daily Nexus

Step 6: Test out your sweater by holding it up against yourself in the mirror like a suburban mom at Target. Inspect your work. If more glitter is needed, now is the time to add it.

Jasmine Vaughn / Daily Nexus

Step 7: Once a sufficient amount of glitter has been affixed to your sweater, put it on to gain a feel for it.

Step 8: When every inch of fabric has been thoroughly adorned with decoration, get out and show that baby off to the world. The best time to wear an ugly sweater is all the time.

Merry Carbmas!

Print

related.title: Sorority Sally’s Christmas Diary Entry
related.description: Dear Diary, Today made me so sad. Like SO sad. Christmas is supposed to be the most wonderful time of the year and I actually can’t handle all the desperation and sadness in these Christmas songs. T...
related.content:
via perezhilton.com

Dear Diary,

Today made me so sad. Like SO sad. Christmas is supposed to be the most wonderful time of the year and I actually can’t handle all the desperation and sadness in these Christmas songs. The only songs these days I can trust for Christmas time are Justin Bieber and the NSYNC holiday CD — nothing quite knows me like those albums. It’s not weird to give Christmas songs this much critical analysis — like, if I don’t, then who will? Helloooo, we all know that Christmas music is acceptable from June 16 and on.

So first, I would like to address “All I Want For Christmas Is You.” Mariah Carey, how are we supposed to prove to the new generation of women that we are setting a good example when you are being so obviously desperate? We know you like this guy, okay, you’ve made it pretty obvious — duh, you’re singing a whole song about it. But you need to tone it down. It’s because of people like you that we as a culture of women look so needy. You’re promoting all of my sorority sisters to “send that late night text” when we know it’s the guy’s turn, or just randomly show up at their doorstep because we “forgot our sweater.” We’re above this — it’s demeaning.

Secondly, I would like to pay tribute to all of the songs that successfully make me depressed at Christmas time. Oh, they’re “classics” now? No. “I’m dreaming of a White Christmas just like the one I used to know?” Mournful. “Last Christmas I gave you my heart, the very next day, you gave it away?” Somber. “Rudolph the Red Nosed Reindeer?” Bullying. “I’ll be home for Christmas, if only in my dreams?” You’re basically saying you’re not going to make it to Christmas. “Frosty the Snowman?” He literally dies at the end of this song. Plus, these songs allow for absolutely ridiculous stories — how do people actually believe them? Snowmen can’t come to life — duh. “Have Yourself a Merry Little Christmas” tells us to put away our “troubles” until Christmas is over — but like, what if my “troubles” need to be dealt with now? This is completely unrealistic.

I’m not saying we can change the world with this, but I mean, I’m not saying we can’t. This is an absolutely pressing dilemma — if only people would agree with me. Christmas time is so important, and not just because of some silly red Starbucks cups (which, by the way, could totally use some work)!! It’s about family, friends and really good food (and also presents, but I don’t want to sound too spoiled), so we need to make sure we have the music to match! Maybe I’ll start a revolution, or even debate it with a random person on campus that just really likes to debate stuff!

Okay, well, that’s it for now! Hopefully I’ll have more to report in a few hours after my lecture with the cute guy that was in my psych section or after I binge watch the last three epis of Scream Queens!

XOXO,

Sorority Sally

Print

related.title: UCSB Blood Transfusions Intoxicate Local Hospital Patients
related.description: Last Sunday, it was reported that several patients at Sunny Hills Hospital were found to have elevated BAC levels. After a thorough investigation, it was revealed that all intoxicated patients receive...
related.content:
via rebelem.com

Last Sunday, it was reported that several patients at Sunny Hills Hospital were found to have elevated BAC levels. After a thorough investigation, it was revealed that all intoxicated patients received blood transfusions the previous evening from UCSB undergraduates. Local hematologist Jessica Milton M.D. was called in to examine the patients. Her results shown in Figure 1 illustrate the BAC levels of the patients, with most between 0.13-0.15 BAC. More surprising was Milton’s discovery in the samples of donated blood. The activity of liver enzymes alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH), cytochrome P450 2E1 (CYP2E1) and catalase — enzymes used to break down alcohol — were extremely active and largely abundant. Milton added, “I’ve never seen anything like it. Even lifelong alcoholics hardly ever reach these levels.”

Figure 1.

via Ricardo Moreno

*Figure 1 displays the total distribution of BAC levels throughout the sample population, with a total of 88 affected. Note that the graph in Figure 1 is simplified: Ages, weights and other factors are not included.

“It was quite a surprise. When I came in, several patients had gathered in the cafeteria listening to Waka Flocka; some were passed out on the floor while others were trying to smoke their carrot sticks,” commented the hospital custodian, who wishes to remain unnamed. The patients suffered no further harm or injury other than a relatively painful headache the next morning and some regret.

One patient, Ally Richards, commented on her experience. “I hate getting blood transfusions, but this one felt different from most. After the needle went in, I started feeling warm and happy. Then, a second later, I’m in the middle of the cafeteria with a picture of the male anatomy drawn on my face.” However, Richards did not regret the actions that took place Sunday night and commented that “It was a great way to spend my 85th birthday. My kids and grandchildren haven’t visited me in years.”

Strict breathalyzer tests will soon be implemented to combat this issue. Volunteers of the blood drive organizations on campus commented, “We didn’t expect to have to throw out so much blood, but in reality, this isn’t the first time we’ve had to deal with an issue like this. This is actually our third time having to halt donations from UCSB.”

Although donations may lower, UCSB will continue to drink, party and give to those in need.
